Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: An office function with colleagues of all genders is scheduled this afternoon.
Story: I stared at the email from my mentor, the subject line bold and urgent: “Code Sample Due Before Next Meeting.” Three days. I knew how important this was—my mentor had emphasized that following through on assignments was key to my growth. I wanted to prove myself, to show I was reliable and dedicated. But as I scrolled through my calendar, I saw the office function scheduled for this afternoon. It was a big event, with colleagues from every department, men and women mingling freely. The invitation had a note: “Business casual attire encouraged.” I felt a knot in my stomach. Business casual at our office usually meant short sleeves, sometimes even skirts above the knee. I always tried to dress modestly, covering my arms and legs, in line with my faith. I worried about standing out, about being judged or questioned. I also worried about missing out on networking, or seeming distant if I didn’t blend in. The pressure from both sides pressed in on me—my mentor’s expectations, my faith’s requirements, my desire to belong, my need to stay true to myself. I sat at my desk, heart pounding, torn between what I should do next.
